title: 106_s1213
content: The "Indian Child Welfare Act Amendments of 1999" grants Indian tribes exclusive jurisdiction over child custody proceedings involving Indian children, regardless of their residence or domicile, if the child resides within the tribe's reservation or becomes a ward of the tribal court. SEC. 3. INTERVENTION IN STATE COURT PROCEEDINGS. Amends the Indian Child Welfare Act to specify exceptions in state court proceedings. SEC. 4. VOLUNTARY TERMINATION OF PARENTAL RIGHTS. Section 103(a) of the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978 is amended to require written consent for foster care, adoption, or termination of parental rights, recorded before a judge and with a certificate confirming full understanding of the consent terms. The Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978 now requires written consent for foster care, adoption, or termination of parental rights, ensuring that natural parents are informed of placement options and notified of any changes in adoptive placement within 10 days. The court must certify the consent and understanding of the terms. The Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978 now requires written consent for foster care, adoption, or termination of parental rights. An Indian custodian with legal authority to consent to adoption is treated as a parent for notice and consent provisions. The Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978 now requires written consent for foster care, adoption, or termination of parental rights, including withdrawal of consent. Section 103(b) of the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978 (25 U.S.C. 1913(b)) is amended to allow revocation of consent to adoption or voluntary termination of parental rights for an Indian child under specific conditions. The Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978 allows revocation of consent to adoption or voluntary termination of parental rights for an Indian child under specific conditions. Upon effective revocation, the child must be returned to the parent. If consent has not been revoked by the specified period, revocation can only occur through applicable State law or court petition. The Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978 allows revocation of consent to adoption or voluntary termination of parental rights for an Indian child under specific conditions. If consent is revoked, the child must be returned to the parent, and any final decree of adoption must be vacated. Adoption in effect for over 2 years cannot be invalidated under this provision. SEC. 6. NOTICE TO INDIAN TRIBES. Section 103(c) of the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978 is amended to require written notice of placement or parental rights termination for Indian children to be sent to the tribe by registered mail within specific timeframes after foster care, preadoptive, or adoptive placements. The Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978 now requires written notice of placement or parental rights termination for Indian children to be sent to the tribe within specific timeframes after foster care, preadoptive, or adoptive placements. Notices must be provided within 10 days of certain proceedings, and if a child is discovered to be Indian after the initial timeframe, notice must be given within 10 days of the discovery. The Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978 requires notice of placement or parental rights termination for Indian children to be sent to the tribe within specific timeframes. The notice provision applies if the party has made a reasonable inquiry about the child's Indian status before placement. The Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978 requires notice of placement or parental rights termination for Indian children to be sent to the tribe within specific timeframes. The notice provision applies if the party has made a reasonable inquiry about the child's Indian status before placement. SEC. 7. CONTENT OF NOTICE. Section 103(d) of the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978 is amended to require written notices to include the name, birth details, and family information of the Indian child involved. The notice must be based on a good faith investigation. The written notice required under the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978 must include the name, birth details, and family information of the Indian child, along with a list of extended family members with placement priority, reasons for potential Indian child status, names and addresses of involved parties in state court proceedings, details of the court proceedings, tribal affiliation of prospective adoptive parents, and information on social service or adoption agencies involved. The written notice required under the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978 must include the name, birth details, and family information of the Indian child, along with a list of extended family members with placement priority, reasons for potential Indian child status, names and addresses of involved parties in state court proceedings, details of the court proceedings, tribal affiliation of prospective adoptive parents, and information on social service or adoption agencies involved. Additionally, the notice should identify any Indian tribe the child or parent may be a member of, state the tribe's right to intervene in the proceeding, inquire about the tribe's intention to intervene or waive intervention rights, and specify that failure to respond by the tribe will be considered a waiver of intervention rights. SEC. 8. INTERVENTION BY INDIAN TRIBE. Section 103 of the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978 is amended to grant Indian tribes the right to intervene in voluntary child custody proceedings in State courts under specific conditions. This includes sending notice of intent to intervene or written objections within a specified timeframe. The Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978 grants Indian tribes the right to intervene in voluntary child custody proceedings in State courts. Tribes must send notice of objection within a specified timeframe to the court or party seeking adoptive or voluntary placement of the Indian child. An Indian tribe can't intervene in a voluntary child custody proceeding in a State court if they notify the court or involved parties of their decision not to intervene or if they determine that the child is not a member of the tribe. If the tribe files a motion for intervention, they must also submit a tribal certification to the court. The certification must document the Indian child's membership or eligibility for membership in the tribe under tribal law. Any action or inaction by the tribe does not affect placement preferences or rights under the Act, nor does it prevent the tribe from intervening in a proceeding if the adoptive placement changes. This provision does not impact the Act's applicability. No proceeding for voluntary termination of parental rights or adoption of an Indian child can occur under State law until 30 days after the tribe receives notice. A court can approve post-adoption visitation agreements for the best interests of the Indian child. Compliance with court provisions is required. The failure to comply with court orders regarding visitation or contact after adoption does not invalidate the adoption decree. SEC. 9. PLACEMENT OF INDIAN CHILDREN. Amends Section 105(c) of the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978 regarding the preference of a parent or Indian child in court decisions. SEC. 10. FRAUDULENT REPRESENTATION. Amends Title I of the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978 to address fraudulent representation. SEC. 114. FRAUDULENT REPRESENTATION. Amends Title I of the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978 to address fraudulent representation. The section addresses criminal sanctions for knowingly falsifying information regarding whether a child is an Indian child or a parent is an Indian under the Indian Child Welfare Act. The section outlines criminal sanctions for assisting in physically removing a child from the United States to obstruct the application of the Act. For an initial violation, a person may be fined or imprisoned for up to 1 year, and for subsequent violations, the penalties increase to a fine or imprisonment for up to 5 years.
